qas.question: What do many people gain from their identity groups?
People favoring those in their group over outsiders, is an example of what?
Belonging and discrimination are both important to researchers working in what tradition?
Distinction between in and out groups has been shown to affect people's evaluations of others in work related to what?
Too many people gain from their social groups?
What issue regarding discrimination have researchers explained?
It is the term for favoring outsiders?
What are researchers working on who focus on discrimination and community alienation?

plausible_answers.text: subtle effects on people's evaluations of others

qas.question: Cognitive distinctions between out groups can lead to what?

context: Many people gain <a0_0>a sense of <b4_0>positive self-esteem<b4_0/><a0_0/> from their identity groups, which furthers a sense of community and belonging. Another issue that researchers have attempted to address is the question of <b5_0>why people engage in <a1_0><b6_0>discrimination<b6_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/>, i.e., why they tend to favor those they consider a part of their "in-group" over those considered to be outsiders. Both questions have been given extensive attention by researchers working in <a2_0>the <b7_0>social identity tradition<b7_0/><a2_0/>. For example, in work relating to <a3_0>social identity theory<a3_0/> it has been shown that merely crafting cognitive distinction between in- and out-groups can lead to <b8_0>subtle effects on people's evaluations of others<b8_0/> (Cote & Levine 2002).
